articles.headline: 2 Top Economists Differ Sharply on Risk of Deflation
articles.snippet: Jan Hatzius of Goldman Sachs and Richard Berner of Morgan Stanley both predicted the recent downturn, but they travel separate roads on deflation.
articles.abstract: Jan Hatzius of Goldman Sachs and Richard Berner of Morgan Stanley both predicted the recent downturn, but they travel separate roads on deflation.
articles.lead_paragraph: When the latest unemployment figures are announced on Friday, all of Wall Street will be watching. But for Richard Berner of Morgan Stanley and Jan Hatzius of Goldman Sachs, the results will be more than just another marker in an avalanche of data.

articles.headline: Senate Confirms Kagan in Partisan Vote
articles.snippet: Elena Kagan’s confirmation is not seen as altering the current closely divided ideological makeup of the court.
articles.abstract: Elena Kagan’s confirmation is not seen as altering the current closely divided ideological makeup of the court.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Senate confirmed Elena Kagan to a seat on the Supreme Court on Thursday, giving President Obama his second appointment to the court in a year and a victory over Republicans who sharply challenged her credentials and record.

articles.headline: G.M. Pushes for U.S. to Sell Entire Stake at I.P.O.
articles.snippet: The chief executive of General Motors said he wanted Washington to sell its entire stake to help shed the stigma of being government owned.
articles.abstract: The chief executive of General Motors said he wanted Washington to sell its entire stake to help shed the stigma of being government owned.
articles.lead_paragraph: TRAVERSE CITY, Mich.  Eager to rid his company of the stigma of being government owned, the chief executive of General Motors, Edward E. Whitacre Jr., said Thursday that G.M. wanted Washington to sell its entire stake during an initial public offering.

articles.headline: Corporate Funds Aid Centers Tied to Lawmakers
articles.snippet: Nearly a dozen lawmakers have been honored by university endowments financed in part by corporations with business before Congress.
articles.abstract: Nearly a dozen lawmakers have been honored by university endowments financed in part by corporations with business before Congress.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Nearly a dozen current or former lawmakers have been honored by university endowments financed in part by corporations with business before Congress, posing some potential conflicts like that attributed to Representative Charles B. Rangel in an House ethics complaint.

articles.headline: Exotic Deals Put Denver Schools Deeper in Debt
articles.snippet: Denver’s budgetary woes were made worse by a complex transaction that went sour in the financial crisis.
articles.abstract: Denver’s budgetary woes were made worse by a complex transaction that went sour in the financial crisis.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the spring of 2008, the Denver public school system needed to plug a $400 million hole in its pension fund. Bankers at JPMorgan Chase offered what seemed to be a perfect solution.

articles.headline: Caveat Emptor, Continued
articles.snippet: Wall Street banks that put together mortgage securities are resisting changes that might convince investors they are safe.
articles.abstract: Wall Street banks that put together mortgage securities are resisting changes that might convince investors they are safe.
articles.lead_paragraph: A few years ago, the securities markets financed hundreds of billions of dollars in mortgages without any government guarantee. Now, those markets are virtually closed to such financing.

articles.headline: Wall St. Faces Specter of Lost Trading Units
articles.snippet: Investment banks like Goldman Sachs are considering how to comply with new rules from Washington governing their trading and investments.
articles.abstract: Investment banks like Goldman Sachs are considering how to comply with new rules from Washington governing their trading and investments.
articles.lead_paragraph: They are the elite among the elite at Goldman Sachs, highfliers who are the envy of Wall Street.
articles.byline: By Graham Bowley and Eric Dash

articles.headline: Top Obama Adviser on Economics to Step Down
articles.snippet: Christina Romer, head of the Council of Economic Advisers, is the second member to leave this summer.
articles.abstract: Christina Romer, head of the Council of Economic Advisers, is the second member to leave this summer.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Christina D. Romer is resigning as the chairwoman of President Obama’s Council of Economic Advisers, the White House announced on Thursday night. She will be the second member this summer to leave an economic team that has steered the administration through the worst recession since the Depression.

articles.headline: Hard-Line Islam Fills Void in Flooded Pakistan
articles.snippet: Flood victims and political observers say the disaster provides another painful reminder of the anemic health of the country’s civilian government.
articles.abstract: Flood victims and political observers say the disaster provides another painful reminder of the anemic health of the country’s civilian government.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHARSADDA, Pakistan  As public anger rises over the government’s slow and chaotic response to Pakistan’s worst flooding in 80 years, hard-line Islamic charities have stepped into the breach with a grass-roots efficiency that is earning them new support among Pakistan’s beleaguered masses.
articles.byline: By Adam B. Ellick and Pir Zubair Shah

articles.headline: U.S. Lost 131,000 Jobs as Governments Cut Back
articles.snippet: Private employers were unable to add enough jobs in July to overcome the loss of thousands of Census and government jobs.
articles.abstract: Private employers were unable to add enough jobs in July to overcome the loss of thousands of Census and government jobs.
articles.lead_paragraph: With the departure of thousands of temporary Census workers and thousands more let go by state and local governments, businesses could not rescue the American labor market in July.

articles.headline: Governments Go to Extremes as the Downturn Wears On
articles.snippet: Strained for funds, governments have made cuts in core services like education, transportation and public safety.
articles.abstract: Strained for funds, governments have made cuts in core services like education, transportation and public safety.
articles.lead_paragraph: Plenty of businesses and governments furloughed workers this year, but Hawaii went further — it furloughed its schoolchildren. Public schools across the state closed on 17 Fridays during the past school year to save money, giving students the shortest academic year in the nation and sending working parents scrambling to find care for them.
